Wow. Just wow. I loved the great acting and the no frills, classic movie making style of this one. Shots were simple yet powerful, with a great group of new pilots that each came across as genuine and unique. Their chemistry was apparent and it showed on screen. I also loved the music. 80's synth pop is my jam lol. The theme of overcoming past regrets and pain through pushing past your demons and seeing what really matters; your pilots. your crew. your loved ones, puts things into perspective.

As an aside it was nice to see a film that was patriotic. The dog fights were stunning, and the whole training sequence where Cruz tries to get his pilots to make the canyon run in a certain amount of time, and how they eventually achieve it is intense. It makes you really grip the edge of your seat, but not in a flashy overly manic way.

Not only THE best movie of 2022, one of the best movies ever. I saw the original and liked it sure, but this one towers above it. And being a kid back then, I didn't fully appreciate what Top Gun was all about. Being a middle-aged man now, I almost want to kick my 8-year old self. The nostalgia is there, sure, but it's just a damn good movie. It's entertaining, it's well-acted, it's well-written, it's well-directed, and it's one of those movies you just enjoy for being a movie. Disney--take notice. Tom Cruise knows how to do it.

It takes a fair amount of suspension of disbelief, but if you can achieve that then this really is a perfect movie. I didn't find the scenario they were in particularly likely and the romance part felt a little forced but the bulk of the movie truly was incredibly entertaining. It probably helped to be seeing it in a movie theater where on each side of us were older couples who would likely have seen the first one in theaters too -- I heard one of them crying during the scene with Kilmer and that added a lot to my viewing experience. The casting was impeccable and the sustained level of suspense throughout the third act was super impressive. I wasn't a big fan of the first movie at all, particularly the airplane scenes as I found them disorienting and couldn't easily tell the planes apart from one another; this one corrects both problems completely, improves on the human drama & isn't worse in any category, not even the music. Kudos!

I saw the first movie as a care free teenager when it was ok to be proud to be an American and you went to the movies to be entertained and Hollywood was still pretty much just doing that. The music started in Maverick and I was swept back to a more peaceful time. Then....he pulled out the jacket! Woohoo!! Then, the motorcycle! This movie is how a sequel is done right! There is a new batch of Top Gun pilots and there is a woman. Sweet. Not once was it shoved in our faces that she had to work harder or be tougher or break a glass ceiling. She was one of the gang. They all worked hard to get where they were, end of story. No agenda! And American flags everywhere!! So refreshing to just be entertained instead of spoon fed "the message". We need more like this!! So far I've seen it 4 times.

I also wish the they would develop more on the premise of the story or the other characters as so that they do not appear as randoms who was there to fill a spot for the story. I guess time limits does limit that to some degree but I will still recommend this movie to anyone just based on the action sequence.

​Described as a - THRILLING - CATCH YOUR BREATH - ACTION BLOCKBUSTER - any additional review provided will be to simply fill in a plot line of what is a Must-See Movie for any and all Action-Adventure movie audiences.
Pete "MAVERICK" Mitchell, AKA Tom Cruise, returns to the big screen Top Gun sequel as a test pilot who has been reactivated by the Navy to train a detachment of TOP GUN Grad pilots for a special mission. Programming note: If you have not seen or watched the original 1986 Top Gun movie, try to do so before you watch/see the 2022 sequel. It will add substantially to your understanding and enjoyment of the movie. The most significant reality of this movie is that you will become part of an audience that will cheer, applaud and laugh out loud as an outpouring of understanding and support for the actors and their actions on the screen. There is a sensation of a return to a time when heroes were men of a character, courage and bravery that made them exceptional. There is a secret mission behind contemporary enemy lines requiring the bombing of a target whose access and destruction will most certainly lead to the death of the pilots being asked to undertake the mission. The skills and almost reckless abandon necessary to train the group of 6 aviators falls to the pilot whose code name is MAVERICK - AKA Tom Cruise - a nickname designated because of his unconventional flying abilities and his recognized disrespect for the rules.  Strap on your seat belts as you become both a witness and member of a team whose flying skills will take your breath away and have you question the sanity and courage of those who risk their lives to save ours. Suggest you arrive early because word of mouth will have audiences lined up for one of the best films screened in a very long time.
Rating: B - A - C - O - D - Bravery Audacity Courage On Display

The ravers are right when it comes to "Top Gun: Maverick". Tom Cruise is seamless in his return to the role of Pete Mitchell aka Maverick of the 1986 original. Ordered to train a group of young pilots for an almost impossible mission, he is still as cocky as ever as he attempts to unite them as a team, despite arising complication from his past that need to be reconciled. The slick film has adrenaline-filled action, but also heart, particularly in its handling of Van Kilmer's appearance as Maverick's former nemesis, Iceman. Its pacing keeps your attention in the way that old-school stories used to, with an engaging narrative and solid performances that make seeing it at the cinema a real experience. The call-backs to the original movie are great, but it also stands on its own merit as a very entertaining film, especially in its exciting flying sequences.

Fantastic movie! I came into Top Gun Maverick expecting it to be a bit dull given that on the surface the movie seemed to be about people flying planes. The movie was never dull. There were multiple thrilling scenes that had me on the edge of my seat. The score is excellent providing a great complement to the action, the triumphs, and the tension. The script was tightly focused on the relevant communications while in the air, but, even outside of the flying scenarios, the characters were well-written and motivated. My only critique was that the romance seemed a bit forced and a little cheesy. However, the movie does a great job of allowing you to escape into the world and get caught up in the action. I highly recommend Top Gun Maverick.

Youve been called back to Top Gun. Top Gun: Maverick is a fantastic film that appeals to everyone, even those who disliked the original film. Not a rehash of the first film, it capitalizes on the strengths of the original while adding much greater sophistication and character development. Its literally the commies who disliked Top Gun: Maverick, while everyone else justifiably enjoyed it. Unlike some recent cinematic disasters, the film wasnt designed to subvert expectations, rather, it meets and then surpasses them. Some have said that the summer blockbuster film genre is heading to extinction. Maybe so, but not today. While the film has a great supporting cast with excellent character development and convincing acting, its all about Tom Cruises Maverick. Naval aviator is not what he is it's who he is... And hes taking you along for the ride. I saw it with one person who hadnt seen the original and another who didnt like the original, but they each enjoyed the sequel.  Top Gun: Maverick is the best film Ive seen in theaters in years, and I promise youll enjoy it. And more importantly, youll feel far better for having seen it. Has all the trouble of the world gotten you down? Its time to let it go and go see Top Gun: Maverick.

What a picture! Cinema at its finest! Top Gun: Maverick is the high energy, funny, exhilarating motion picture cinemas and audiences need–and–it's full throttle heart! Furthermore, the absolutely brilliant combination of screenwriting, directing, and all the technical elements combine to acknowledge and build upon the nostalgia without resting its laurels on it or hiding behind the cultural and cinematic touchstone that was the original Top Gun. I didn't know a long-awaited sequel more than 30-years from the original could be THIS good–in fact–it's better than the original. We are talking Wrath of Kahn compared to Star Trek the Motion Picture here. Maverick represents that some stories, characters, and themes are truly timeless. Even the most casual fans of the original will be touched by everything this film has to offer. I cried several times, and I am not alone. Multiple fellow critics have remarked this film moved them to tears as well. Familiar, yet fresh doesn't begin to capture the magnitude of diegetic and cinematic success of delivering the surprisingly perfect experience of this film that could very well be on its way to Best Picture of the Year nominations. Maverick is the film that we need as a country, as a world right now! Its plot is equal parts character and action-driven, and no scene or character is wasted or simply inserted to satisfy some nostalgia checkbox. Not only a love letter to the cinematic phenomenon that was Top Gun, it's ostensibly a love letter to the cinematic experience in terms of scale and scope of the adrenaline-pumping high-flying adventure! We need this film at such a time as this. It's an uplifting, positive, constructive motion picture for all! Fly, don't walk to your nearest cinema that offers premium formats like IMAX or Dolby to experience this epic story on the BIG SCREEN.

I've been waiting for 30+ years for this sequel and wasn't disappointed at all, as the movie delivered on everything I was hoping and expecting from it. 

A big thing that you just can't overlook is how they used the past "nostalgia factor" to the maximum, where it brought me into a roller coaster of emotions and it clearly paid off. The movie didn't just explore the present era but also used the past to connect the two together in a masterful way. The story was good and believable plus the fact that no CGI (except for the enemy fighter jets which are SU-57 NATO designation "Felon", Russia's 5th Gen aircrafts) was used for the flight/dogfight scenes, definitely made the movie to be in a league of its own. The only reason that they had to use CGI to show off the Russian SU-57 "Felon" fighter jets was that I am sure Russia would not have permitted the use of their own best new 5th generation aircraft for an American movie where their aircrafts are blown out of the sky by 4th generation American fighter jets. 

The work these actors including Tom Cruise had to go through to capture the reality of all events was simply masterful and you see why Tom Cruise delivers again and again as a box office draw, even after decades of movies. Anyone who saw the 1st "Top Gun" 1986 movie have to see this movie because it's beyond a cult culture movie. I know this sequel is the last "Top Gun" movie and it saddens me because after watching this movie, I was left wanting. But, as the saying goes "All good things must come to an end". And this movie had it all, from start to finish. It gave me shivers and the nostalgia factors made me choke at times. That's how good this movie brought out emotions from the viewers who were of age to see the original 1986 movie when it first came out. 

Nothing in this movie was overboard, everything was carefully measured so that it would have a multitude of moments that touched every chord of emotions. I remember when the first Top Gun movie came out, the military had an incredible influx of men/women wanting to join the military's every different branches, some wanted to be pilots, some infantry, Army, Marines, Rangers, some special operators and so on. I wonder if this sequel will have the same effect of patriotisms that the first one had? 

Bottom line, if there's only one movie you could/would see out of all the other movies that are out and coming out right now, "Top Gun: Maverick" is the movie to watch. There's never been a movie like this and nor will there be another movie like it ever again. It's perfect in all its multiple facets and worth every penny to watch. So, if there's only one movie you can watch this summer, "Top Gun: Maverick" is the one to watch. I've already seen it 3 times.

I can't believe all the good reviews. It was too long, too boring, too obvious, too dumb. I know you have to suspend disbelief for a movie like this - but his plane disintegrates (and for some reason that knocks out all the electricity at some kind of command center tracking him) at 60,000 feet doing over 7,000 mph (Mach 10), and next scene he walks into a diner just looking shaken and thirsty? He would have been vaporized.
All the Goose references were boring and overdramatic, as were most of the scenes with Maverick and Rooster. The love interest was just tossed in because there had to be one. The beach football scene was only there because of the beach volleyball scene in the original. Many scenes seemed unnecessary and overly long (with lots of too long closeups of concerned looking faces).
At over 2 hours it was an hour over what it needed to be. I nearly walked out mid-movie, but knew there had to be an exciting climax with the fighter jets (which was quite good). Wait until it's streaming, and just watch the last half hour, minus the last 10 minutes of hugging.

Loved the aerial scenes but thought some of it defied believability, e.g., Maverick's fighter jet is hit, crashes, and yet he's lying in the snow alive and unhurt.  Then gets up and runs, literally, to meet up with Rooster.  Really?!
Perhaps my expectations were too high!

Wow, went with my dad to see this as an early Fathers Day present and it was well worth it, I love this so much and there's plenty to talk about so I'll break it into sections. 

Also Fun Fact: My dad worked on the plane used in the opening credits, and it was so nice to see him excited to see it even if it was only there for a few minutes.

Score: Whilst they still use a lot of the original soundtrack like Danger Zone, they add a modern spin on them through remixes and plenty of new and catchy songs, even if it's not as perfect as the original song-wise. Reusing the songs also fit the fact that it's more of a requel, as it mixes in a lot of the old stuff whilst not sticking to those conventions of cheesy 80's movies, allowing this to be more unique and beautiful.

Cinematography: It's surprisingly gorgeous for an action movie, and sometimes it can even be the focus above the action which I'll always appreciate. They use a lot of bright colours, summertime hues (oranges, reds, yellows, and bright saturation to create a very cosy environment. It definitely gives off summer blockbuster vibes, leaning into that meta cheesiness they use like the original did. They also choose their landscapes very carefully making the environment feel more lived in, and it adds a contrast to the military zones so you feel different when in both separate areas: more controlled in the military but less in nature as you have less control over it. 

Acting: Another Tom Cruise movie that's basically just him being himself, minus all the running. Miles Teller is the star here, and his role is just the perfect legacy to Goose in the 1st Top Gun. He juxtaposes Maverick really well and their passive-aggressive dynamic throughout is the highlights of the movie, much like Goose and Maverick in the 1st; their dynamic at the end is even better, and I love how they tie this in with him and it's so beautiful and surprisingly emotional. Rooster also is so likeable, and it's so impressive how similar to Goose he is. Icebox is the other legacy character, and everytime I see him I just can't stop feeling bad for Val Kilmer, as he tries his best but what he's reduced to is honestly heart-breaking, but for what he can do they utilise him to the best he can. Phoenix and the rest of the supporting cast are all pretty memorable, minus Fanboy and Payback who don't get much screentime till the end, and even then they don't do much to make them memorable sadly. On the opposite, Hangman is another really interesting side as he has a stereotypical douche role but his development makes me like him way more than I should, even surpassing greats like Malfoy, etc. The one character I couldn't get behind was Penny, as she's during the period inbetween the two films so she doesn't get a proper introduction and just feels so forced and basic, like she's a love interest but she's only really funny and I liked the end scene in the plane but apart from that I didn't get behind her character at all. 

Plot: Another Top Gun movie about planes, dogfighting and missiles but with a surprising amount of heart behind it. Being a faithful requel that respects the original is a godsend, and it feels so much more impactful and emotional than it should. Goose is really well developed and the plot revolves around letting go of the past by welcoming in the future and it was a nice sentiment that helped end the franchise on the best possible note. The villains were extremely basic intentionally, kind of dehumanised which was an interesting choice that I respect but I wish they created higher stakes as the training was more intense than them. The ending fight was insane and perfect, with improved CGI and way better visuals that made the dogfights truly memorable and the best parts. The only thing that fell flat was the romance between Maverick and Penny, as it felt half-baked and having her be established between the two films but never properly introduced makes her so bland and the only thing that feels like a true cop-out in this movie, which is a shame as it had potential if another legacy character was instead returned or had they set here up better.

Overall: The second best film of the year behind The Batman, but such a great time and I'm so glad I experienced this in the cinema with my Dad, who's a huge Plane nerd and we just had the widest smiles on our faces the whole movie.

My wife tells me that I need to be better about suspending logical thought when I see a movie, and I find this difficult.  Although this movie is entertaining, there are several significant plot flaws, that range from illogical details to the inane.  I'd discuss them here but that would create spoilers, so I'll resist.  Nonetheless, this was highly entertaining, fun, and suspenseful.  

As far as Tom Cruise goes, I think he did a very good job in his role.  Would I call it his best role?  No, he can actually do better.  If you want to see him at his best, watch Vanilla Sky or Born on the 4th of July, or even Jerry McGuire, which are far better displays of his acting abilities, and better material for him to show that he actually is quite a good actor when he gets something more intelligent to do.  Frankly I wish he did more serious roles, but that is hard to resist when you can make big bucks doing action flicks.  Poor Tom, I bet he is crying all the way to the bank :-)  .

Good quality scripts can lead to highly enjoyable films. Equally, it depends not only on directors but on playwrights. Mostly good scenario is devasted by bad directors or even a good director couldn't fix a bad plot, and yet the film I'm going to tell you about is a showcase of how directors and screenwriters can cooperate. While they have their drawbacks, Top Gun: Maverick precisely shows us amazing air stunts and yet realistic ones.
Top Gun: Maverick tells us a story from the perspective of  Pete Mitchell, nickname "Maverick" played by Tom Cruise. As the film starts we see him getting ready to become the instructor of Top Gun graduates to prepare them for the dangerous mission.
Except for known characters in the film from the previous one, you will see a few completely new ones. Although there are a lot of new personalities in it, they are connected to each other. There are different storylines within the main one. I almost forgot to mention the amazing soundtrack with songs from such popular stars as One Republic and Lady Gaga. Also, I want to admit the work of cameramen). This film is suitable to watch with family due to its PG-13 rating.
All in all, Top Gun: Maverick is well-casted, well-filmed and well-scripted. If you like aircrafts, realistic air stunts and dogfights, you have to watch it.

Vastly improves upon from the original Top Gun in so many ways. The script is more coherent, less cheese, less boring, the action is several times more tense and authentic, and it gives just the right amount of humor. There is solid music choices some classic returning hits and some new hotness. When things really get tense, there is no music, and leaves me missing some of those '80s bangers revving up the moment. But it would consequentially alter the mood and lower the intensity in said moments. Probably was honestly a good move. It's as awesome of a sequel anyone could ask for, especially this late in the game. Kudos to the director, camera crews, actors and military advisors.

I really did NOT want to see this movie.  I really love military aircraft and want to like movies like this but the original Top Gun is just a meh movie in my mind.  There was too much forced drama for the sake of drama and the cool jet sequences just didn't make up for it.  So I was very hesitant to see Maverick.  But I was wrong.  It was a super enjoyable movie.  It's almost all wrong, in terms of what airplanes can do and how the military employs them, and usually that is enough to make me dislike a movie.  Somehow, Top Gun: Maverick is enjoyable enough, good enough, and fun enough to allow me to see completely passed all the shenanigans with planes pulling G when they're flying straight, prohibited maneuvers, moronic mission plans, magic SAMs, incorrect CM being used, poor tactics, and a pilot who would be kicked out of the Navy for half of the things he does.  I recommend it.  I'd watch it again.  I'll probably try to purchase it at some point.  It's a good show.

Top Gun: Maverick was originally going to be released July 2019. Then pushed to March 2020 for added sequences. But due to Covid it was delayed to December 2020, then July 2021, then November 2021 then finally May 2022. The lion's share of this movie was shot four years ago. Was it worth it? I say yes. Sequels of iconic films done decades later are under so much scrutiny. Many times actors put off doing sequels in their prime. They wait until the phone stops ringing to cash in on reprising their most memorable roles (think Harrison Ford). Therefore this type of sequel costs vastly more and the pressure is sky high to produce a profit. 

Then there's us. We want lightning to strike twice. Unfortunately most times it doesn't. But in my opinion, Maverick delivers. Yes the nostalgia is spilling all over with the 80s music, shirtless football, Goose's son, Rooster playing "Great Balls of Fire" on the piano in the bar and Hangman is Iceman light...but Tom's performance is rock solid. He's not playing a cocky kid. Pete Mitchell is a grownup who shows the latest hot shots that they're not as hot as they think and prepare them for an impossible mission (wink). I was glad to see Val Kilmer make a cameo. I would have liked to have seen Tom Skerritt return as Viper. Do the Tom's not get along? 

The movie is legit. It checks all the boxes but it's not all rehash. The story breaks new ground in new territory as well. It's a fun ride. And that's about as good as it gets.

Exceeds expectations and lives up to the hype! Easily surpasses the original in almost every way imaginable! In a time when studios are constantly resurrecting old films, this is how you breath life into an old IP and make a film worthy enough to be called a sequel.
-------------------------------------------

More than 30 years after the first film, we see Captain Pete "Maverick" Mitchell still flying planes. He's engulfed in a secret scramjet project that's building a prototype capable of flying to Mach 10. His team has successfully tested to Mach 8, and upon hearing the program is getting shutdown by the military for falling behind schedule, he puts his life and career in danger, pushing the aircraft to Mach 10 and beyond.
-------------------------------------------

Instead of taking the fall as expected, he's sent back to the TOPGUN program to train an elite group of graduates tasked with an urgent bombing mission. The risk and difficulty of the mission requires strenuous training, and his superiors are skeptical that Maverick is up to the task. He soon discovers that "Iceman", his rival-turned-buddy from the first film, put in a good word and personally requested his assistance. He also learns that the son of his late best friend "Goose" is part of the elite group he'll be training and goes by the call sign "Rooster". Their relationship is strained, as Maverick delayed Rooster's advancement to the Naval Academy (based on a promise to Rooster's late mother that he would prevent Rooster from following in his father's footsteps).
-------------------------------------------

There are plenty of flashbacks and callbacks to the original "Top Gun", as Maverick gets to know his students and rekindles a past relationship in town. Iceman passes away, setting the stage for Maverick's removal from the program by Vice Admiral "Cyclone" Simpson, who is not a fan. In a last-ditch effort to prove he's needed, he flies an F/A-18 without authorization through the simulated training course. He completes it in record time, winning the reluctant approval from Cyclone. Maverick is appointed strike leader and forms his team, which includes Rooster.
-------------------------------------------

This is where the film really begins to shine. The animosity between Rooster and Maverick explodes to the forefront, and his fatherly approach to the situation makes you feel an emotional connection to the characters. You're rooting for both of them the rest of the way, and in the final act, the film hits a grand slam with an edge-of-your-seat, fist-pumping adrenaline rush. It tugs at the emotional strings at the right moment to cap off one of the best endings I've seen in a very long time.
-------------------------------------------

While the film may struggle at times to appeal to all genders and ages, it has a lot to offer to everyone, especially fans of the original. It seems like many of Bruckheimer's projects these days are hit and miss -- mostly miss -- but Top Gun Maverick will blow you away! The cinematography is next level good, and if you're a fan like I am of James Cameron's slow-panning, immersive action shots (think Terminator 2 or Avatar), you'll be glad to know this non-Cameron film has plenty of that as well. In an era where movies rarely use that tactic any more in favor of close-up jerky movements, it's a sight to behold when you come across a film that does.
-------------------------------------------

Top Gun Maverick


Top Gun Maverick lived up to the hype in the second action packed sequel. I am glad I watched this movie on the big screen especially for the second part of the movie when the actual mission was in full swing. After almost a month since the release date, the theatre was still at 90% capacity in this post pandemic world. A good movie to encourage more big screen attendance as I can assess.

As for a potential threequel, I'd like to see less macho scenes with the new generation of pilots. Some of the scenes were far fetched to say there least but it was still very entertaining. I would like to see a threequel which focuses more on internal and domestic issues even within the executive branch. Not to get political, but there audience needs to be aware that the external threat portrayed in the sequel is not the most realistic scenario. Focus on internal division leading up to 2024 and beyond and how that translates for the future regardless which side of the aisle you sit on. Domestic and internal threats should be in focus. On the plus side, Maverick did acknowledge that drones and autonomous aircraft are the future. People will still watch these type of movies if you keep it realistic. All in all, three most entertaining movie I have seen this year.

Fighter pilots must bomb narrow opening in mountainous terrain to take out nuclear reactor in hostile country with misfit pilots who were never cut out to carry the mission to begin with. The movie was atrocious. No real thought put into, same tired plot, different actors. The F-14 vs. SU-57 scene was so far out of touch with reality, I couldn't even laugh. It was just disappointing. The dogfighting scenes and maneuvers were equally unrealistic and so far from reality it was just very disappointing. The original was so much better and it will always be King.  C- grade. This sequel was as at least as good as the original Top Gun movie. It had the same or even more surprises and suspense than the original. Great acting by Tom Cruise, Miles Teller and Bashir Salahuddin as well as Jennifer Connelly and it goes without saying: Val Kilmer. it was a great touch that Val Kilmer was not only included, but his character provided the all-important reasons for Maverick to remain in and excel in the Navy and give Maverick the push to do what he did best and saving lives as a result.  It was great to see Val, the person, on screen as well. As Gooses son, Rooster was a great story within the movie and Miles was exceptional. Penny and her daughter, with Mavericks history, added tender family and support touches within this outstanding movie. Charles Parnell, Monica Barbaro, and many of the other actors/actresses completed what I believe to be one of the top ten movies Ive seen in my lifetime. And thats a very long time. 
Considerable keys to also mention include the use of high-tech filming as well as the actors preparations. It would be a tough decision to weigh the original against the sequel. Maybe Top Gun III will tell the tale.

Everything you want from Top Gun, and then some. This story has all the nostalgia and callbacks to the original you want, but without being a complete do-over. In some ways, the story is even better than the first and not overly bogged down in Maverick's own ego. Flight scenes are INCREDIBLE - hats off to the aviators who made those on-camera maneuvers. The only reason for the missing half star is for the far-fetched-ness of the ending. If you're a fan of the franchise, you'll have no problem overlooking it, as it's still enjoyable as heck... but you will have that inner voice going "oh, come on... really?" for a few minutes. After that final scene gets going though, you'll be back on track and loving every second again. Definitely worth the price of admission and not a dull moment in the entire film.

Top Gun: Maverick is a near-perfect action movie. The dialogue and plot are clear and concise, so the focus can remain on the action at all times. There is just the right amount of humor, which springs naturally from the characters and the plot, so there are no eye-rollers shoehorned into the script. And the actual footage of fighter jets (as opposed to CG) performing the most incredible feats are really what the movie is about. I don't know for sure, but I don't think there's a single green screen or CG plane in this movie. It's incredible and filmed magnificently (including actors in the cockpit for every shot). Really worthwhile, and you can watch it with the kids!

I was a big fan of the original and have probably seen it 10x (if not more), but was looking forward to seeing the sequel.  However, in my view--other than the flight scenes which are worth seeing--the casting and acting is terrible.  Jon Hamm was completely unbelievable and is certainly no Tom Skerritt.  There was zero chemistry between Connolly and Cruise and watching their scenes together was cringe-worthy.  The Top Gun pilots in Maverick don't compare at all to the original--"Goose", "Merlin", "Slider", "Hollywood" and "Wolfman" were great in the original.  This cast of pilots is really bad, even Powell who plays the knock-off "Iceman" (even looking much like the young Val Kilmer in the original).  Dialogue is forced and not very authentic.  I hesitate to call this a "sequel" because it is really almost more a remake.  Everything is predictably just like the original...even the stupid beach football game that is the replica of the volleyball game in the original.  I was really disappointed and confused at how people could watch this movie and like it (other than the entertaining flight scenes).

Think of Goose and his wife, played by Meg Ryan, in the first film. They are both a ton of laughs. Methinks their son would have inherited some of that. Minor issue. The entire cast was well put together and everyone had a moment to shine. Top Gun Maverick is a delight. It picks up where the original left, and uses the same recipe that made the first one a landmark of American cinema. Amazing movie! Been waiting since I was a kid to see a sequel to Top Gun. Everything about this movie is realistic, moving, and thrilling. I went from moving back and forth to the edge of my seat, to nearly crying from emotion evoking scenes, to laughing with the rest of the audience. The entire cast was amazing! There was a perfect balance of dominating and quiet personalities, egos and humility, hot shots, and pilots not so sure of themselves, and hotties and geeks. Every element of the movie was well thought out, down to the music, the camera panning, scene transition and scene length, and we can't forget the footage from the planes like no other that I've seen in a movie. Thank you Tom Cruise for making this phenomenal movie and for making it the most unforgettable, moving, and thrilling movie I have ever seen.

This is the kind of movie we need more of! Yes, there was nostalgia, but it was appropriate and there was still a fresh new story. I totally bought Tom Cruise as Maverick 30+ years later. Characters were interesting and the stakes always felt earned. I also loved how certain moments that the writers could have done the same thing as the first Top Gun, they didn't. I also loved how they never had to explain "This is Penny Benjamin, you know the girl Mav went ballistic with...." blah blah blah. I loved how the writer and director understands we are smart enough to figure that out (even if you didn't see the cast list already) without doing what just about every other director does these days which is explain everything to us in detail, rather than trusting the audience's intelligence. Also, loved the real planes, real pilots. This is what makes the movie. Definitely a cinematic experience. And the filmmakers are smart enough to know that if you are going to tell a story about the need to have real pilots instead of drones and technology, it's probably a good idea to tell that story with real planes, real pilots, and real effects, otherwise the entire movie is hypocritical. Bravo! Please, please, please...give us MORE of these types of movies!

So few sequels ever live up to the original in a film series.  One that springs to mind is Aliens, which--in my humble opinion--was even better than its predecessor.  So when it comes to producing a sequel to one of the most famous, beloved movies of all time, the task seems just about impossible.  When I heard it was coming, the fact that it was decades after the original also worried me.  

Imagine my complete surprise--and utter delight--to finally watch Top Gun: Maverick on the silver screen.  It's a mach-speed romp comprising everything from the perfect pinch of nostalgia to some really satisfying character development to a little romance and comedy to a LOT of fantastic, edge-of-your-seat action sequences.  This movie has EVERYTHING in perfect proportion.  It could've been just a rehash of everything in the original, but it's not.  It could've overdone the nostalgia, or crossed the line from poignant to cheesy, but it doesn't.  Congrats and cheers to the filmmakers, actors, and crew who managed to pull off this miracle--because I think Top Gun: Maverick is actually even better than Top Gun.  Yeah. I said it.

People seem shocked that Top Gun Maverick is able to pull off what it does. To a certain extent Tom Cruise has already made this movie though. While wildly different in tone and context The Color of Money was the sequel to a film that was 20 years old. Again they don’t share much, but at a 30,000 foot level they had to accomplish many of same things. Chiefly to introduce a cast of new characters, create stakes for their involvement, but still keep their focus on the original protaganist and his character arc over time. New Hollywood seems obsessed with sacrificing the diginity of the old to “hopefully” sell you the new, but that formula never works out, it is sort of marketing angle awry. If we are lucky the executives at the studios will unleash a collective ‘Oh, thats how you do this’ and we will get better sequels. I hope so.

Warning: Spoiler Alerts! The film started off promising but it kinda lost its legs after the opening sequence. Not bringing back previous characters from the first film, most notably for Iceman’s funeral, was a big letdown for me. The film also could have ended on a higher note if Maverick would have requested permission from the tower for a fly by but instead he just does it without saying a word. The supporting cast was very subpar with the exception of Jon Hamm and Jennifer Connelly. In the end, it’s another big budget Hollywood production with a very predictable plot line.

Have you ever seen one of those movies that just blows away all expectations... this was like that, arguably more so than any other movie I've seen. It's right up there with Terminator 2, Aliens and Empire Strikes Back as one of the best sequels Hollywood has ever produced. You'd never think a movie made 35 years after the original could pick up in a logical and consistent place, particularly with Hollywood's tendency to absolutely massacre legacy characters and franchises of late (Last Jedi, Independence Day Resurgence, Jurassic World Dominion, etc...). But this movie picks up without missing a beat off the 1986 original with Maverick still the same cocky, self assured, rule breaking naval aviator he always was, albeit a bit wiser, more world weary and obviously older which makes perfect sense being that it's been 35 years. But the core of who he is, and what Top Gun as a movie was, hasn't been altered in the slightest. Throw in some of the best practical effects you've seen outside a Christopher Nolan movie in decades and you start to realize just how tired the whole deference to CGI has become and how much you've missed the real, or near real, thing. I can't recommend this movie enough, particularly on the big screen.

The first one wasn't that great. To be honest, as somebody who only watched it because it was one of the "classics", I wondered throughout the whole movie, what led to people liking it so much and therefore declaring it legendary. I found my answer in the ending, especially the iconic handshake. The scene created this feeling inside of me, that I cannot describe in words. It simply felt awesome and triumphant. Well, Top Gun Maverick created that same feeling. Though this time, the feeling lasted two whole hours. The emotions in this movie are incredible. One moment I'm sitting on the edge of my seat, the next I have tears in my eyes. I wasn't sure if the movie was worth a trip to the theater for me. I'm not the biggest Tom Cruise fan and as I said, the first part didn't really impress me. But the positive feedback finally convinced me and I thank God for that. The action sequences are incredible. I felt every G-force going through my body. Shivers kept running down my spine and I had goosebumps throughout. Every storyline the movie starts, ends and leaves the audience with satisfaction. The acting is incredible too, Tom Cruise delivers a perfect performance, while being supported, as well as enabled by the great Miles Teller and the rest of the cast.This movie is a masterpiece, a true roller coaster ride from start to finish.

Awesome movie in every way! It's hard to follow-up a classic but this did a great job. It's awesome to see real jets flying, instead of CGI. It's nice to see real human characters, instead of majical superpowers. Everything about this movie is believable. Although Tom Cruise was to focus of this movie and he did a great job, Miles Teller was they key. If Miles did a bad or unbelievable job, it would have ruined the movie. Well he just knocked it out of the park with a great job! Casted perfectly, acted perfectly. Small spoiler alert: My only minor complaint is that Maverick didn't choose Hangman for the mission. He was portrayed as the best, so he should be on the mission. I understand completely why they did it, but in my brain, that didn't make sense. But what a great movie! There are very few movies that I would like to see again in the theatre and this is one of them. Great job to Tom Cruise, cast and entire production/filming crew!

It really doesn't hold a candle to the original, but that doesn't mean it's a bad movie. It's just not as fun, not as quotable, and it's far too predictable. The filming in the cockpits is good though, although nothing groundbreaking if you watch IMAX flight movies and search YouTube for the hundreds of Navy and Air Force videos out there. The way the movie revolves around Goose's son is a decent angle, although you feel like Mav got closure at the end of the first movie, so it's unclear why we're reopening that can to the point where a movie revolves around 30 years of him carrying the weight. They did a nice job of tying in old characters and story lines. It's kind of fun that they gave Penny Benjamin a face, although a bit more backstory on what happened to Charlie and how Penny became on-and off all these years would help. Anyway, a good amount of redeeming qualities here, but plenty that held it back as well. There are a few spoilers in here for the few who haven't seen it. 

Why it's not as good as the first:

- Blatant Star Wars Rip-off - Young man who has grown up being told his father is dead is asked to fly a small fighter through a narrow canyon to avoid canons/air defense to fire missiles into a small vent to blow up a larger target. Oh, and much like Luke Skywalker, he does it without his "targeting computer". There's even a "Han Solo shoots the enemy fighter right as it's firing to kill our hero" moment. Oh, and to show how much the director stuck to the Star Wars script, Maverick 'held Rooster's papers to keep him from going to the academy' exactly like Uncle Owen held Luke's papers to keep him from going to the academy. Hollywood really struggles for new content, but that's a pretty blatant rip-off.

- The Characters are not well developed and aren't nearly as fun as the original. That was disappointing. The character of Goose's son is a major disappointment compared to the character of his dad, who was phenomenal in the original.

- Top Gun: Maverick is not a quotable movie. The first movie had people walking out of the theater quoting 20-30 lines. The dialogue in the first movie was phenomenally well written. This movie is a major letdown in comparison. I'm not sure there's a single quote I will carry with me from this one. What a shame.

- The Director failed in ever getting you to believe the main characters were truly in trouble. There's really no suspense in that regard. You want to be able to feel some tension as you're watching. It's not there.

- Every major thing that happened seemed to be predictable. You could say "something's going to happen" and predict what that something was every time without fail. Would be nice to throw a red herring or two out there once in a while to keep the audience on their toes.

The dumb Hollywood drivel that's far too common:
- Maverick rides his motorcycle at high speed into a restricted area without anyone batting an eye.
- An Admiral stands underneath the path of an airplane as it takes off. The plane lifts the roof off the building the Admiral is standing next to. The Admiral is not knocked over. He doesn't flinch. I really hate when Hollywood does this stuff.
- Maverick is doing tight bank turns at Mach 9+ at one point. Really?
- Maverick is wearing his jacket with insignia that clearly says, "Capt Pete Mitchell" while at a bar. Young Lieutenants continually disrespect him and throw him out of the bar. No way should the Director have had him wearing his name and rank if he wanted to pull off that scene.
- There's a scene where two pilots are shot down in different parts of an unfamiliar forest, and one manages to sprint straight to the other, despite no line of sight. Again, really?

Why it's still solid:
- It's well filmed. Getting the actors to not throw up in the cockpits did add something to it this time, although it's also quite clear they are back seating in some scenes. Still very quality cinematography. It's not necessarily anything you can't find on Military or Smithsonian Channels or on YouTube (there are 100s of high quality videos from inside fighter cockpits these days), but it's still fun to see it on the big screen. 
- Like I said, nice job tying in characters from the first movie. 
-The mission was actually fun as well, even if it's a complete Star Wars rip-off.
- The plot is solid. It has some minor holes but it's really not a bad story. 
- While there's some significant slowness in early and mid-scenes, it moves well in the latter parts and keeps you entertained once it really gets going.

All in all, a solid watch and good on the big screen, but not nearly as fun as the first.

Its a marvel and a tribute to the 1986 OG. The intro gives you goosebumps as it takes you back to the OG, same opening sequence with Danger Zone throttling through your veins! That line aviators call it TOPGUN! Shivers!!! Chills!!! 

However, Tom Cruise takes this one to an another level. He is old,  he is greyed but boy he has not lost his style! He carries the film on his shoulders. Be it the air sequences or dialogues or acting! This is Cruise's film. The support cast though delivers a solid performance.

The air sequences are just Wow! A special callout to the opening sequence: the Mach 10 and the climax sequence. The climax giving tribute to the OG by bringing in the F-14 Tomcat. There was hint early in the film that the Tomcat could make an entry. But one couldn't be sure!

As a fan who grew up seeing the OG on VCR, DVD multiple times. This was a fitting closure to finally see the TOPGUN on big screen!

Kick the tires and light the fires! What a ride of a movie. Top Gun: Maverick delivers, from the moment you hear Harold Faltermeyer's iconic theme you know you are in for a treat. This is old-school Hollywood, you know, when movies did what they were meant to do, entertain you. The movie does a great job respecting the original and its characters and then it did something I was not expecting... it surpassed the original in every way; This is one of those rare gems that is actually better than the original. 

It took 30 years to make this but like a fine wine, it is exquisite. If you love the original the sequel will not disappoint. You have to see this in a movie theater don't wait to see it at home. The sound is incredible in the film you feel those jet engines every time they come on the screen, the only thing missing is the smell of the exhaust.
